clue: Pixar's proprietary rendering software used to generate final images from 3D scenes
the process of generating a final image from 3D data, including light, shadow, and motion
a tool that defines the surface appearance of 3D objects, including skin, metal, or glass
a modeling technique that smooths polygon edges by dividing them into finer geometry
a rendering technique that simulates how light bounces to produce reflections and shadows
automated animation of elements like hair, cloth, or water based on physics
the goal of rendering that aims for images indistinguishable from real life
a simulation engine created to animate fur and hair automatically based on physics
a shading system that mimics blurry translucency like jellyfish membranes
Pixar's internal rigging tool for realistic muscle and skin deformation
a lighting model that simulates light passing through translucent food items
an ocean simulation algorithm used for choppy waves in Cars 2
a digital skeleton that allows 3D characters to move in animation
a setup that mimics how skin and muscles deform when a character moves
a simulation framework used to create and animate garments realistically
a digital tool that mimics real-world cinematography inside 3D software
a reference for smooth, stable camera motion used in CG animation
a stylistic camera approach that adds realism by simulating operator movement
a lighting effect that simulates how light enters a surface and scatters inside (used for skin and food)
the path light takes through a transparent or translucent material in rendering
a simulator developed to handle Merida's 1,500 curls and simulate curly hair physics
a lighting technique used to simulate the way curly hair transmits and scatters light
a lighting system that simulates how light bounces and scatters in a scene based on real-world physics
special lighting setups used in Monsters University to enhance spooky scenes
a lighting tool that turns characters into mobile light sources, used to make Joy glow in Inside Out
3D clouds made of particles that can be lit and moved in scenes like characters
modular volumetric cloud components used to build realistic skies in The Good Dinosaur
a technique used to control flexible motion in characters, e.g. Hank's tentacles in Finding Dory
a method to preserve texture detail at different distances by simulating surface roughness
a system that helps cloth avoid intersecting with complex skeletons in real time
a technique that preserves cloth texture detail during stretching and compression
a specialized rig that calculates realistic key movement based on finger position
a simulation approach for soft or unstructured materials like stuffing
a rig that combines animation and simulation to control different body parts
a rig that allows animators to control where and how a character transforms in real time
an unintended error or distortion in rendered imagery, often due to compression or lighting issues
a technique that simulates handheld motion to add realism or intensity to a shot
combining multiple visual elements from different sources into a single image
the visual arrangement of elements within a frame
the range in a shot that appears sharp, often used to draw focus
a modeling technique where a shape is extended to create depth
a visual effect that simulates light scattering from a bright source, often used for stylistic emphasis
a single still image in a sequence that makes up a moving picture
the number of frames displayed per second in a video or animation
a background replacement technique using chroma keying to isolate subjects
isolating an element in a shot by removing a specific color range, usually for background replacement
a physical model used as a reference for creating digital characters or sets
the process of tracking a camera's movement so that CGI can be composited accurately
a digitally created or enhanced background used to extend or replace live footage
a collection of vertices, edges, and faces that defines a 3D object's shape
a visual effect that simulates streaking of moving objects between frames
detecting and replicating movement from live-action footage into 3D space
rendering a scene in separate layers (e.g. lighting, shadows) for compositing
a modular unit used in node-based software to perform visual or data operations
random variation in image brightness or color, often used to create texture
a visual effect where objects at different depths move at different rates
a small point-based element used to simulate effects like smoke, fire, or dust
the technique used to represent three-dimensional objects on a two-dimensional plane
the process of creating 3D models from multiple photographs of an object or environment
the original footage shot on set, before visual effects are added
a flat, two-dimensional shape used as a basic unit in 3D modeling
creating rough versions of shots or sequences to plan visuals before production
the planning phase of a film or animation project, including concept art and storyboarding
the stage after filming where editing, VFX, and audio are finalized
a network of computers used collectively to speed up rendering tasks
the number of pixels in an image, determining its visual detail
a color model using red, green, and blue light to create a full spectrum of colors in digital imaging
tracing over live-action footage to create animated sequences or isolate elements
an annual conference showcasing innovations in computer graphics and interactive techniques, including VFX breakthroughs
a virtual hackathon by the Academy Software Foundation that guides first-time contributors through their first open-source VFX or animation project task, with mentorship from maintainers
drawing sequences of shots to visually plan out a scene or film
a specialist responsible for solving technical issues in the production pipeline
converting digital media files from one format or compression to another
the process of projecting a 2D image texture onto a 3D model's surface using coordinates
a scripting language used in Houdini to control simulations, shaders, and procedural effects
a volumetric pixel, used to represent 3D data in simulations or medical imaging
